subtitle: so my previous emp video is now the most
viewed on my channel
so i thought let's make another one this
time bigger and more powerful
the main component for this build is a
10 000 volt neon sign transformer
which can do this
the first step is to replace this pull
switch with a red momentary button
to do so we need to take apart the
casing
so as you can see here is the pull
switch and this is what we need to
remove
so right now i'm trying to free the two
wires that connect to the switch
now we need to solder these wires to the
new momentary button
but first we need to extend each wire so
the button can fit outside the box
i'm also using some heat shrink tubing
to make sure the transformer doesn't
accidentally turn on
this is what it looks like when we're
done and now we can thread them back
through the
initial hole
this is what it looks like now and the
button will be connected towards the end
of the project as it is the last piece
for the housing of the emp we'll use
this dolphin torch
this is a design diagram for the emp and
it's basically the same as the previous
one
in the middle we have our neon
transformer and this is encased in our
torch housing
it's powered by our dc output wire
and this creates a high voltage which
leads to the spark cap
in my previous emp video i had a lot of
people ask what the spark got was for
and what it does
basically when the spark occurs it
discharges the build up of charge
resulting in a change of magnitude that
leads to the electromagnetic field
so i hope this cleared that up this then
leads to the
magnetic copper wire coil which outputs
the electromagnetic field
and then it links back into the
transformer
and this is all controlled by the switch
which were the two wires we were wiring
up earlier
now we need to get the torch casing
ready for the transformer
so i ran into a problem early on the
transformer was a bit too big for the
casing
so my solution was to cut a hole in the
back of the plastic
this allows us to fit the transformer
properly and also have the plug coming
out of the back
this is what it looks like when it's
been cut and now all the wires and the
transformer should fit properly
for the coil we'll be using this two
millimeter thick enamel coated copper
wire
and for the spark gap the prongs will be
these two nails
so one high voltage wire will be
connected to a nail and the other will
be connected to the copper wire
both nails are hot glued onto the
transformer box so they stay secure and
don't move around
our other nail will be placed at an
appropriate distance for the spark gap
before attaching the other nail to the
copper wire i sanded off some of the
enamel coating on the ends so that it
will conduct properly
next i drilled two holes in the acrylic
face to allow both ends of the coil to
stick through and connect inside
once this end of the copper wire is
through the hole we can connect it to
the nail
now that the wires been connected we can
create the coil by wrapping the wire
outside the box in a circular shape
once i cleaned it up and added zip ties
this is what it looks like
i also hot glued the coil to the face
and if we turn around you can see that
both wires are sticking through the
holes into the inside
i also ran into another problem which is
that the cap must twist on
this makes it impossible for me to
attach the wires and the nail
to the top of the transformer to get
around this problem i decided to
sand off the grooves so that the cap
could just be pushed on
now the cap can be pushed on straight
and everything should work now however i
will be adding some hot glue later to
make sure it's secure
now it's time to attach the other high
voltage wire to the copper and the nail
on the transformer
so this is what it looks like when both
nails have been attached to their wires
and now the spark gap is complete
next we need to replace the button with
our red momentary switch
the two wires we were working on earlier
will now come up through the handle and
out of the hole at the top
now that i've got the wires through we
need to attach it to the switch
but first i'll run some hot glue around
the neck to attach the cap
once the button's in place the emp is
finished and this is what it looks like
when the button is pressed a spot gap
will occur sending tens of thousands of
volts
through the copper coil creating an
electromagnetic pulse destroying small
to medium-sized electronics from about
a meters range so let's go test it out
so
before the video ends guys i just want
to say thanks for watching and if you're
new please subscribe
i will be uploading more regularly and i
have some good videos coming up

others
